item.title: Chef‚Äôs Table, il classificone degli episodi della seconda serie
item.description:
Chef‚Äôs table √® la pazzesca serie di documentari di David Gelb che racconta i migliori cuochi del mondo. √à su Netflix. Se la prima serie era gi√† abbastanza speciale (c‚Äôera anche Massimo Bottura, che in questi giorni √® diventato una specie di numero uno al mondo), la seconda ha accentuato ancora di pi√π i punti forti dello show: estetica foodporn e grandi storie personali degli chef protagonisti. Ogni stagione 6 episodi, questa √®, senza tante parole, la mia discutibile classifica dal migliore al peggiore.

1. Dominique Crenn di Atelier Crenn, San Francisco, Usa.

Ragazza francese, adottata, dolcissima, misteriosa, apparentemente con una vita solo per il suo ristorante, anzi ristoranti (ha anche un bistrot, Petit Crenn). Serve men√π presentati come poesie, prima donna a prendere due stelle Michelin. Nel documentario si dilunga sul padre che non c‚Äô√® pi√π, le telecamere la seguono in Francia, ci sono continuamente foto di lei da piccola. Poi tutto si connette: ogni foto sembra spiegare ognuno dei suoi piatti. Merita, e poi gli altri sotto hanno gi√† avuto le loro soddisfazioni.

Best quote: ¬´It‚Äôs not about us creating dishes. It‚Äôs about connecting everything, from the start to the finish¬ª.

Best dish: Non importa, come dice lei. Ma l‚ÄôHoney apiary non sembra male.

2. Grant Achatz di Alinea, Chicago, Usa.

Lui √® il vero numero uno della serie. Molto chef, moltissimo artista. Cucina genere ‚Äúoltre‚Äù: ti fa mangiare su cuscini che liberano profumo di noce moscata, oppure serve palloncini di zucchero. Storia pazzesca: gli diagnosticano un tumore alla bocca, lo danno per spacciato, trova quasi per caso una cura sperimentale, cucina avendo perso il senso del gusto per mesi, poi lo ritrova. Nel frattempo chiede al suo executive chef, Mike Bagale, di realizzare un palloncino alimentare. Lui ce la fa.

Best quote: ¬´All chefs want to be known for using a knife. Cutting, creating, saut√©ing‚Ä¶ doing all of that. But maybe that‚Äôs not the most important thing. Maybe the most important thing is taking the idea, that little nugget, and handing it to someone else. And the next thing you know, someone is holding a balloon¬ª.

Best dish: Tropical fruit with rum, vanilla, kaffir lime. Ovviamente servito direttamente sul tavolo. I tipi di Chef‚Äôs Table ne hanno fatto l‚Äôimmagine di copertina della serie.

3. Alex Atala, D. O. M., San Paolo, Brasile.

Lui √® diventato una star davvero. Di questi primi tre, √® forse quello da cui mangerei pi√π volentieri. Ex punk, diventa il messia della nuova cucina brasiliana, usando solo ingredienti locali. Il documentario inizia con un suo sogno, fatto una sera dopo che aveva preso troppi acidi (vedi frase sotto). Al 7¬∞ minuto sgozza un gallo come se stesse sbucciando una banana. Al 13¬∞ copre d‚Äôoro una formica amazzonica. Al 15 si fa una cucchiaiata di salsa di formiche che sanno di lemongrass. Al 26¬∞ squama con un coltello di mezzo metro un enorme pesce Pirarcu. Al 36, tra una lezione sulla tapioca e i suoi derivati, si fa pure un match di judo contro un malcapitato e un bagno nudo e tatuato in acque amazzoniche. Si fa due cuori di palma abbattendosi da solo l‚Äôalberello. Gran finale sulla storia dei suoi tatuaggi (mica pochi).

Best dish: The Amazonic Ant. Ma anche il Pirarcu con farina di manioca, tucupi e tapioca.

Best quote: ¬´A plant has a circle. A seed becomes a plant that has a flower, it transforms into a fruit. The fruit drops. There‚Äôs another seed‚Ä¶ and the seed grows again. This is a circle. And I said: ‚ÄúI see. I understand. But why did you show me the flower?‚Äù. And he said: ‚ÄúThe flower is the moment that we live, the most beautiful moment of the circle. The most beautiful moment. Contemplate this‚Äù¬ª.

4. Gaggan Anand, Gaggan, Bangkok, Thailandia

Indiano che trova fortuna in Thailandia. Decide di fare cucina prog indiana, s‚Äôindebita, perde un fratello, va a studiare al Bulli, ma alla fine ce la fa.

5. Enrique Olvera, Pujol, Citt√† del Messico, Messico.

Praticamente il re della tortilla sofisticata. Anche lui ha un debole per le formiche, che usa per una salsa in cui stufa del mais.

6. Ana Ros, Hi≈°a Franko, Kobarid, Slovenia.

Talentuosa chef, in piccolo paese di piccolo Paese. Delicata, acuta, sofisticata. Unica pecca: meriterebbe una stella Michelin, ma in Slovenia non ne danno (ma sar√† vero?). Marito sommelier che appare un po‚Äô saccente.

item.title: The struggle for the open web
item.description:
What if, one day, you discover that your fulfilling social media life was completely wrong? What if your castle of self gratification and instant connections, friends and followers, mobile power and desktop automation would fall apart? We do not need an incoming Apocalypse to ask the right questions, we just need to stop one moment and think.

I‚Äôve been walking around in a kind of a daze for weeks and everywhere I go I find myself scribbling something down: open web first. Open. Web. First.

The open web is the internet we build together out of the social media walls. It‚Äôs the post you write on your own blog, the note you take and share, the snapshot of a moment. It‚Äôs something you make for the whole web, out of Facebook, out of Instagram, Twitter, Tumblr, Medium and any other well engineered social media platform. Then you distribute it and link it as you wish.

Why do I care about the open web? Because it‚Äôs open. Because it‚Äôs the web itself.

It is a content distribution system one can control. For contents that you ultimately own and certainly you can share. Actually thinking ‚Äúopen web first‚Äù gives you the opportunity to share twice: 1) with the whole internet; 2) with any social platform and any restricted circle you desire. It‚Äôs something I can easily search and link, a liquid matter of knowledge we all can own and control at any time of our life. Not only a flash of a moment, an insta-something of truth you can miss just because you weren‚Äôt following the right dude at the right time.

Think about your social routine today: posts living only on Facebook, buried in endless timelines. It can be acceptable if you‚Äôre sharing the photos of your cat, but if you‚Äôre a communicator, in the public square, you should think ‚Äúopen web first‚Äù and get control of your content.

You can start reading about it following Dave Winer‚Äôs blog posts, or studying the IndieWebCamp wiki. They wrote about the open web better than me. Then you can rethink your paradigm, or keep going on, knowing even more.

Yes, we have a problem: open web should be for the masses, but now it‚Äôs not that cool to join. It‚Äôs 2016, social platforms are easy and beautiful and powerful: they can gather all your friends with a glance of an API, give you instant likes, compress your videos, make you an influencer. They gain value of your content, but - if you can use them, if you‚Äôre creative enough - they pay you back. They also can get closer to the open web we have in mind, check Medium‚Äôs latest efforts and you‚Äôll understand.

An open web tool can be difficult, I‚Äôm learning the hard way trying that transition: you have to set up your own server, find a CMS, learn some coding, find your way to share your content after you publish, protect your vault. You can lose time and immediacy, you can swear and cry, make a mess and start again. It‚Äôs what we do when we change our daily habits and start living better. It‚Äôs what you do when you start eating healthy, put on a pair of shoes and start running your first mile, when you collect your garbage properly, when you discover you can even floss every day (never been able to do that). It‚Äôs good for you, it‚Äôs good for the environment. And, somehow, it‚Äôs also ‚Äúshakespearesque‚Äù.

‚ÄúThere must have a moment, at the beginning, where we could have said ‚Äì no. But somehow we missed it‚Äù.
- Tom Stoppard, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead

PS: easter egg, find the paragraph I totally stole from West Wing, S03E10, Bartlet for America.

item.title: Purity non √® un romanzo sull'internet
item.description:
Non so ancora bene che cosa pensare di Purity, l‚Äôultimo romanzo di Jonathan Franzen, pubblicato finalmente in Italia da Einaudi e tradotto alla grande da Silvia Pareschi (lei ne scrive anche qui). Non lo sapevo dopo aver chiuso l‚Äôultima pagina e lo so ancor meno adesso che so che diventer√† una serie tv con Daniel Craig. WTF.

Era un libro da cui mi aspettavo molto sull‚ÄôInternet (tutto parte da una specie di Julian Assange) e che invece mi ha portato molto a riflettere su altre cose: il matrimonio, il rapporto madre-figlia, la costruzione di una reputazione. Poi dentro c‚Äô√® l‚Äôego di Franzen, ci sono i suoi dannati uccelletti (lo scrittore √® un bird-watcher), i capitoli diario (gi√† visti in ‚ÄúLibert√†‚Äù), i diversi punti di vista, l‚Äôautoreferenzialit√†, l‚Äôossessione sessuale un po‚Äô da romanzo americano con la solita ragazza che la d√† via ‚Äújust because‚Äù.

√à un libro, per√≤, che offre tante sottolineature. Cos√¨, quando ho visto sul Post 16 battute dal nuovo romanzo di Franzen un po‚Äô mi √® dispiaciuto perch√© io sono mesi che meditavo di scrivere qualcosa, avendolo letto in vacanza l‚Äôottobre scorso. Per fortuna, o perch√© io non ho capito niente, i nostri punti di vista non coincidono. Quindi, incollo qui quello che ho sottolineato.

Purity ‚Äúsottolineato‚Äù

Sometimes you imagine something for so long, you find that you have no choice but to do it.

Do you know the Rolling Stones song ‚ÄòHave You Seen Your Mother, Baby‚Äô?‚Äù ‚Äú‚ÄòStanding in the Shadow.‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄúThe very first time I heard it, on RIAS, I could tell in my gut that everything they‚Äôd told me about the West was a lie. I could tell it just from the sound‚Äîthere was no way a society that produced that kind of sound could be as oppressed as they said it was. Respectless and depraved, maybe. But happily respectless, happily depraved. And what does that say about a country that wants to forbid that kind of sound?‚Äù

The world was overpopulated with talkers and underpopulated by listeners,

Her father had approved of her sneaking. He operated by Old World rules, the blurring of right and wrong into whatever you could get away with;

She felt loyal to a baby in her that hadn‚Äôt even been conceived yet. To a possibility.

She was remembering the old desolation and feeling it again now, the conviction that love was impossible, that however deeply they buried their conflict it would never go away. The problem with a life freely chosen every day, a New Testament life, was that it could end at any moment.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúit‚Äôs difficult to trust a person with no secrets.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want to hear my theory of secrets?‚Äù ‚ÄúDo I have a choice?‚Äù ‚ÄúMy theory is that identity consists of two contradictory imperatives.‚Äù ‚ÄúOK.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs the imperative to keep secrets, and the imperative to have them known. How do you know that you‚Äôre a person, distinct from other people? By keeping certain things to yourself. You guard them inside you, because, if you don‚Äôt, there‚Äôs no distinction between inside and outside. Secrets are the way you know you even have an inside. A radical exhibitionist is a person who has forfeited his identity. But identity in a vacuum is also meaningless. Sooner or later, the inside of you needs a witness. Otherwise you‚Äôre just a cow, a cat, a stone, a thing in the world, trapped in your thingness. To have an identity, you have to believe that other identities equally exist. You need closeness with other people. And how is closeness built? By sharing secrets.

Naturally, I bore the brunt of this. A wrong word at the breakfast table or a distracting smell from something I was cooking (‚ÄúSmell is hell,‚Äù she liked to say) could ruin a workday.

You have a right to be happy for yourself. If you‚Äôre with someone who can‚Äôt be happy, you need to think about what you‚Äôre going to do.‚Äù

Don‚Äôt talk to me about hatred if you haven‚Äôt been married. Only love, only long empathy and identification and compassion, can root another person in your heart so deeply that there‚Äôs no escaping your hatred of her, not ever; especially not when the thing you hate most about her is her capacity to be hurt by you. The love persists and the hatred with it. Even hating your own heart is no relief. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd ever hated her more than I did for exposing herself to the shame of my refusing to speak in Leonard‚Äôs voice.

You could cooperate with the system or you could oppose it, but the one thing you could never do, whether you were enjoying a secure and pleasant life or sitting in a prison, was not be in relation to it. The answer to every question large or small was socialism. If you substituted networks for socialism, you got the Internet. Its competing platforms were united in their ambition to define every term of your existence.

The apparatchiks, too, were an eternal type. The tone of the new ones, in their TED Talks, in PowerPointed product launches, in testimony to parliaments and congresses, in utopianly titled books, was a smarmy syrup of convenient conviction and personal surrender that he remembered well from the Republic. He couldn‚Äôt listen to them without thinking of the Steely Dan lyric So you grab a piece of something that you think is gonna last.

It seemed as if the Internet was governed more by fear: the fear of unpopularity and uncoolness, the fear of missing out, the fear of being flamed or forgotten.

Nature even on the most local of scales made a mockery of information technology. Even augmented by tech, the human brain was paltry, infinitesimal, in comparison to the universe.

Matter was information, information matter, and only in the brain did matter organize itself sufficiently to be aware of itself; only in the brain could the information of which the world consisted manipulate itself.

‚Äî POSSEed on Medium | Twitter

item.title: Facebook is eating the world
item.description:
Social media hasn‚Äôt just swallowed journalism, it has swallowed everything. It has swallowed political campaigns, banking systems, personal histories, the leisure industry, retail, even government and security. The phone in our pocket is our portal to the world. I think in many ways this heralds enormously exciting opportunities for education, information, and connection, but it brings with it a host of contingent existential risks

First, news publishers have lost control over distribution.

Second, the inevitable outcome of this is the increase in power of social media companies.
